prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for breaking up with my boyfriend after getting a good job?
I’m 29 and my now ex boyfriend, Justin is 20. We had been dating for a little over a year. I’m to lack of a better word piss poor and to make a living I had been taking odd jobs here and there. One of those jobs was cleaning apartments. The area I live in is becoming gentrified so you have low income apartment dwellers like me next to to upper class people like Justin living in luxury condos just couple miles away. 

I met Justin as I got hired to clean his apartment. Justin has Aspergers and was a awkward at first, but he’s a sweetheart you know. We got to know each other pretty well, he was funny and attractive and before you know it I took his virginity and we started having sex. I was going to tell him its strictly casual, but he started to like me a lot and he would buy me groceries, new clothes like a really nice winter coat, and I had even moved in with him out of my crumbling apartment building. I had lost my job with the apartment cleaning company as well and had to get a lower paying one so Justin was kind of my meal ticket.

Don’t get me wrong Justin’s nice, he’s attractive, and he’s good in bed, but I just don’t love him like he does. Recently though I got offered and took a really good job at another cleaning company that paid really well. I’ve built up a hefty amount savings because I didn’t have many expenses with Justin. I broke up with him a week ago and he’s devastated, I tried to console him and tell him he’d find another girl, but he wouldn’t hear it. I told him we could still be like friends with benefits, but that just made him angry. I moved out and into a new apartment, but I still kind of feel bad about Justin. 

Am I the asshole? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's dive into this situation. The user is asking if the person who broke up with their boyfriend after getting a good job is in the wrong. The scenario involves a 29-year-old woman and a 20-year-old man with Asperger's. They were dating for over a year, she moved in with him, and he provided financial support when she was unemployed. Now that she has a better job, she broke up with him.

First, I need to consider the dynamics here. The woman was in a job that paid poorly and had to take odd jobs. Justin, who is 20, is in a more stable financial position. She didn't love him as much as he loved her, and after securing a better job, she ended the relationship. The user is asking if she's the asshole (AITA).

Looking at the key points: She didn't love him, he was her financial support, but she moved on after gaining financial stability. The question is whether breaking up was justified. In relationships, mutual feelings and personal growth are important. If one person isn't reciprocating the emotional investment, ending the relationship isn't necessarily wrong. However, the timing might be questionable if she used his financial support to get her footing. But she mentions she didn't love him, so staying in an unloved relationship could be seen as unfair to him. 

Asperger's might affect his ability to understand the breakup, but that doesn't make her wrong. She tried to console him, which shows some consideration. The main issue is whether her actions were selfish. She didn't owe him a relationship just because he helped her financially. People have the right to pursue their happiness and life goals. 

However, some might argue that she led him on by moving in with him and accepting his support without loving him back. But if she was honest about her feelings, it's not her fault. The problem here is that she wasn't in love and realized it when she could support herself better. 

In conclusion, the author isn't in the wrong because she ended an unreciprocated relationship for her own well-being after gaining financial independence. The answer should be B.
